segments.text: from every five years.
Well, that's right, but most of us don't have enough courage to do so.
That's the truth of that matter.
Why did you choose to leave ONR?
Well, it came about in 1965.
Paul Feig
came down to see me in Washington and asked me if I was interested in coming up here and working at Woods Hole.
And I met with he and Noel McLean, who was chairman of the board at that time.
After meeting with him a little while, I told him no.
I was happy and O and R. I didn't think I wanted to leave at that time.
The reason I was doing something in ONR that I thought made a lot of sense, and I wanted to kind of follow through.
And the problem that, again, Hugh McClellan, who was in ONR working for me at the time, and I went over to see Walter.
Again, we're talking to Walter Monk on this.
saying, gee, well, what are the experiments that's equivalent to what ARPA is doing on this large array they're putting in?
We ought to be looking at experiments in oceanography that are really pushing the frontiers ahead.
We got to thinking that we really need to understand the circulations of the oceans better.

that there ought to be a fairly comprehensive program that looked at currents over fairly large areas of the ocean with current meters and so on that had acoustics in it that you could compare it with what the acoustics paths were and look at it acoustically and just look at a bigger piece of the ocean than the little ways that, you know,
Essentially, at that time, all the measurements were made just at one spot.
So you had to just take a bigger piece of the ocean and look at it different ways.
And so I was kind of getting that started.
And it was a new thrust.
And I wanted to see it through.
And I was working a little bit on trying to reorganize oceanography in the Navy.
So I was enjoying life in Washington.
didn't think much about leaving.

After that, that summer, Gil McClellan and I came up to Woods Hole and spent a week up here talking to people about doing this, and it looked like Woods Hole was kind of the logical place to do it because there were more people interested in it here than anywhere else.
And I brought my wife up with me at the time.
We kind of
got to like it up here the week we spent here.
I asked her whether she liked it so much she'd like to live up here and she said she thought she could.
So I went back and thought about it a little more and called Paul up.
This must have been nearly a year after he asked me to come up here and I said, are you still interested in having me come up here?
He said, sure.
So I decided to come up.
This was a little bit of a
personal thing for me, too, because I'd gotten divorced and remarried about a year or so earlier.
And I think it made me, I'd stayed in Washington long enough that things had settled down after that period, but then I felt like I'd like to kind of start over again somewhere else.
And I think that all had a part in the decision to come up here.
starting out sort of a new life and a new career all at the same time.
And Woods Hole looked like a nice place to do it.
There were a lot of opportunities here and a great group of people to work with.
And I had a chance to follow through on the kind of program that I was interested in there in the Navy.
Although it's not my particular field of interest doing work, I was interested in the program.
buoy program that is up here developed out of that and it's just made major strides in understanding the oceans.
Did, did you, except for this idea, what other sorts of ideas did you try to bring to Woods Hole when you came as an administrator?
Oh, I uh, I think uh, I, the main thing I think I thought was the uh, the kind of feeling that uh,
that you really had to be doing the best science no matter what you're doing here, and that you really worked on quality at all times.
You're getting the best people here, and we strive for that.
It's something the institution has always done, tried to get the very best people here and develop a good research program no matter in which area it's in.

followed through a little bit on geophysics since I've been up here, and I used to go to sea more often than I do now, because I still have an interest in geophysics, and I think I still have an impact on the programs up here.

As a matter of fact, I spent most of the morning discussing some of our programs that we're going to do, and I think I have some input to shaping these, and although I don't take part in them myself, I feel like I have
fairly good input into deciding what's going on or helping decide what's going on.
Well, I have a couple of questions, one of which you can ignore and one which I don't want you to ignore.
First of all, it seems to me Woods Hole stresses more than other institutions the idea of students going to see.
Is that deliberate?
Yes.
I think the thing that we stress and going to see is only part of it.
We take what I think is probably a little bit different look at the graduate students than other places.
We feel very keenly that it's a transition from classroom learning to doing research on your own independently.
We like to get the person involved in working in the laboratory on problems of his own and going to see solving these and so forth.
de-emphasize the classroom training.
We really want the guy, when he gets his degree, to be able to go off on his own and do a piece of research in some reasonably short period of time.
Now, Scripps was good at doing this when I was there, but it took the average guy seven years to get through the business.
You had a lot of courses and so on, and then you went to C. We're trying to do the same thing in a reasonable time that's normal in graduate schools.
You know, four years is probably, four to five years must be a fairly normal period for going from the BS to the PhD.

What we've done is cut down the amount of class work and got people really doing research, and that means going out to sea, getting involved with problems, getting your feet wet in this business, and knowing what research is, running programs.
I think our students that have come out here are,
very good, and I don't think they lack any of the basic skills that they get in other places.
It's just a different emphasis, I think, on teaching.
It's one of teaching them more pragmatically the kind of things that they're going to be doing when they get out of school.
They aren't going to continue going to classes when they're out of school.
They're going to be faced with working in a laboratory somewhere and doing research.
Was that the question you wanted me to ignore?
That's the question I wanted you to answer.
I'm going to ask you a follow-up question on that too, but another question which you can ignore.

Many of the older oceanographers, that is, I don't mean particularly in age exclusively, I mean those people who came through in earlier time in oceanography regardless of age, felt as if the sea experience was essential to be an oceanographer, identification with the environment.
Do you feel that this is a necessity?
Oh, absolutely.
I'm one of the older ones.
I'll go a little further than that.
I think it's not only essential to go to sea, but I think an oceanographer's got to have a broad base of understanding that is beyond his own specialization.

I feel strongly that he ought to know something about geology, the physical oceanography, biology, chemistry, and so forth, that this is just part of your education to be an oceanographer, to be able to converse in these other fields and know something about it.
I'm afraid a lot of the places that teach oceanography now gets very highly specialized, and I include ourself among this.
Our physical oceanographers here think it's a waste of time to take any biology or geology, and they want them to just take the advanced math courses that they need.
And a student only has a limited amount of time.
Nonetheless, we feel that even these guys that are just taking the math courses ought to go to sea.
And you have to have some sort of feeling with the data that you're working with and the accuracy.
If you're working just with numbers all the time or in the lab and you don't go to sea, I think you just have the wrong feel for it.

Now, I also think that Woods Hole, probably more so than any other place, is an experimental place where people go to sea, more people here go to sea than probably any other oceanographic institution.
That's the way we do things here.
Everybody expects to go to sea.
That's the way we do oceanography.
Scripps is a much more highly theoretical group where a lot of people that are sitting in the labs don't go to sea as much.
It's a different way of doing things now.
I'm not saying one way is better than the other, but our way of doing it is the experimental way of going to sea.
You know, we have a number of people that have grown up here that have no formal educations.
Two of our department chairmen don't have their Ph.D. And two others that I know of that are here have received some of the highest awards in oceanography and have no graduate training.
So they've just learned on-the-job training type of thing.
And they're very good.
They're just first-rate.
And I think that's something...
that it's difficult to do now, even here, but in the past it was difficult to do other places.
Woods Hole was a place where people came and were interested in going to see, went to see, and became oceanographers.
Yeah, this is still not the question, but it looks to me like academic training and institutional organization works against your theory.
It's almost as if
everything in the academic world, including your own institution, is becoming more rather than less specialized.
Oh, I think you're right on that, and a number of us don't agree with that, but we don't prevail either.
I think, as a matter of fact, I think the institution is very nearly 50-50 split on this, and what we do is let
each group kind of go its own.
The physical oceanographers have tended to be very narrow.
Some of the others tend to be much broader.
And I'd like to encourage the broadness, but we don't force it on anybody.
We have classes open to everybody.
We say on their exams they're going to be responsible for knowing this, but they don't have to take courses now.
I went to school at Scripps, and all the courses in the basic subjects were mandatory there.
I would much prefer that here, and a number of other people would prefer it here.
Mostly people that are graduates of Scripps, I might add, feel strongly this way.
But some of the other people here feel very strongly that you want to keep it narrow.
So we've got kind of an in-between.
course on that, and I think it's probably a healthy course.
There's arguments for both sides on this.
The time is limited, and whether you give a guy a broad general education or you specialize in which is the best way to train him in order that he can compete in today's market, I'm not sure.
In any case, going to sea broadens a person, so that's a real advantage to get them out at sea.
And I don't know whether you've had a chance to talk to any of our students here.
No.
We have a great group of students, and I'm sorry you didn't get to talk to Fran Shepard while he was here, or maybe you have talked to him.
I've not talked to him.
I'm going to try to find him at Scripps in November.
Because he met with our students, and he told me he thought it was a great group of students here.
He was really impressed by it.
Did you have any problems making, doing your tenure here?
Did you have any problems making it?

what amounts to not a major shift, I don't mean to imply that, but certainly a movement to the left, where you turned from what had been primarily a research institution into one that was a combination teaching research institution?
Oh, yes.
This has not come easy at all.
This was just taking place when I came to Woods Hole, and that was essentially under one of the conditions I came that we would
push in that direction of making it an educational as well as a research institution.
Surprisingly, there was objection within the Navy to see us go.
They preferred to see us continue just being solely a research.
However, we had a special committee of our trustees set up to look at the question.
They decided that we ought to get involved formally in education.
We made this decision.
had our charter changed to allow us to give a degree.
We have had students here through the whole history of the institution, but usually they were somebody else's students, Brown's or Harvard's or MIT's or something.
And we wanted a group thatwe wanted to make sure that they'd continue coming here, because there were new centers of oceanography being set up everywhere.
We were afraid that each of these schools would set up their own groups and we'd end up with no students here.
And students are just the lifeblood of any research organization.
They're the new ideas and the enthusiasm that comes in.
And so, in essence, what we wanted to do was have a mechanism that would ensure that we had students, had our charter changed,
We decided about that stage of the game that it made a lot of sense to join with MIT in a joint program, which has been successful.
And they had their charter changed at the same time, so we could both give a single degree jointly.
And our student has grown up to, we have about 80 at the present time.
And it's a very healthy, it didn't
come without pains.
A lot of the older staff members objected to it, still object to it, and won't participate.
Very few of the younger people object to it, and they're the ones that are most active in it.
So, in the long run, it'll all wash out and nobody will notice this transition.
So, and I suspect that's, that's Paul Fye's major accomplishment since being director is getting the education program.
I think he would probably think that, too.
It's going to be the one that will have the most lasting effect on the institution.
Well, your question.
What direction is your research field going?
What do you think is going to be the major problem that your research field will have to handle in the future?
The major scientific problem?
The major scientific problem.
Oh, I think...
the major scientific program that is facing the geologists, geophysicists right now is essentially the nature of the driving mechanism of the seafloor spreading plate tectonics.
We know a good deal about the upper layers of the earth, the sediments and the crust of the earth.

beginning to get interested in the deeper parts, how the crust in the lithosphere and the athenosphere, which are the deeper layers in the earth, change from younger crust out to older crust, and when it goes down into a trench, what happens to it there?
Is there a transition between, there is a transition between that oceanic and continental.
Is one eventually transformed into the other, or what?
It's this whole problem of
understanding the deeper layers of the Earth and how they change with age, and the comparison of the oceanic with the same layers in the oceanic with the continental areas.
And these have a multitude of ramifications to them in that if you understand the nature as to what's happening and the mechanisms that's driving all of these, it gives you a much better feeling for
where you look for resources in terms of either minerals or petroleum and so on.
Already the seafloor spreading has paid off on this and the whole work.

I remember the first conference I went to sometime ago in Princeton where we got a bunch of oil companies together with a bunch of scientists talking about seafloor spreading and how it affects where you look for petroleum.
And at that time, the petroleum companies weren't really much interested in that.
They could cite a few examples where the wells off Nova Scotia, I guess, corresponded with the wells off the counterpart in North Africa or something like that, where they pulled apart.
But there hadn't been much work.
Now I think all the oil companies are well aware of the whole theory of plate tectonics, and it's a guiding factor in where they look for petroleum.
I think that's a major thrust, is going to be understanding the nature of the dynamics of what's driving the lithosphere.
And I suspect that's going to be difficult in coming, because we have no direct way of getting measurements on these.
It's going to have to all be done by indirect measurements, at least in the foreseeable future.
But then that's the way seafloor spreading came about.
It was all indirect measurements that really discovered it.
And then the drilling came along and it just confirmed
all of these hypotheses that were put forward.
Then you begin to get direct samples from down there, and then you could make some measurements to test out what you thought was right.
What do you intend to do?
In the future?
Do you intend to move back into research?
Well, I'd like to.
On the other hand, I think I'd find it
very difficult to keep up with some of the younger people.
They're awfully bright.
There's nothing I'd rather do than that.
I worry about how I might be able to compete with them, that they have different skills.
New groups come along.
I've not followed the literature as closely as I'd like to.
It'd be a major job to
get back into it.
I do hope to get a little more involved in research than I am now.
As I said, I've been here 12 years, essentially doing what I'm doing now, and I think I'm getting a little stale at it, and the job's suffering, because I am getting a little stale at it.
I ought to be thinking of doing something else.
I
I just don't have in mind what right now.
I take it, though, that you foresee the remainder of your career here at Woods Hole.
Is that fair to say?
Well, I don't see any other alternatives at this time.
I suspect the deciding factor on that will be if something comes along that's interesting enough to attract me somewhere else.
Fair enough.
Now, the last series of questions I have are sort of general questions, which I'd like for you to make a comment on.
If you were to give advice to a young student, a student of science who wanted to become an oceanographer, what would you tell him to work in?
What particular field?
What particular field?
I don't know.
I guess one could answer that either from what you think the opportunities are or what your own biases are in this.
I think I would urge that whoever was to get interested in oceanography ought to have a good solid background in math and physics, no matter what field they use.
getting into.
I think this is just sort of a fundamental thing that they should have.
Now, there are a lot of interesting things going on in the chemistry and certainly the geology and geophysics.
I find a lot of challenging things still going on there.
The physical oceanography is interesting.
The one area that I wouldn't recommend people to get into, and that's only because there are so many people in it, is biology.
For some reason, biology attracts more people than the other fields.
And there are more biologists competing with one another.
It's not that the field isn't interesting or challenging.
If I were advising a young person, I just would advise him to avoid that unless he has some extreme interests or talents in biology.
And there's no doubt that anybody who's good in any of these fields will
make their way.
I suspect the field of oceanography that's going to do the most in the future is what one might call engineering or applied.
It's the untapped area.
I think what I mean by this is essentially

taking all the knowledge that's gained from the physical oceanographer, the chemists, the biologists, geologists, and so on, and translating these things into useful ways of using the oceans, either through applications or through the design of equipment and processes that will utilize the oceans.
I think this is the big area in the future where we'll see a lot of it, mainly because of the limitations the world is facing in resources, energy, and so forth.
They're going to turn to the oceans for a lot of these, and that's going to be a wide open field for the engineer out there.
I guess it's engineering in its broadest sense.
Well, as a matter of fact, I anticipated my second question, which had to do with ocean engineering and the environment.
Would you assume that ocean engineering, and your institution in particular, will move more and more into what amounts to eco-movements and eco-studies?
Yes, I think so.
Again, this is a trend that's happening everywhere.

world is essentially driving us towards learning more about the ocean as an ecosystem and taking advantage of it I'm sure that as time goes on a larger and larger fraction of our work here will be in the quote the applied areas it's going to be on problems that people are interested in for one reason or another either for resources for pollution or
energy or something like that, that more and more of our effort will go into that, either directly or indirectly.
Again, this is a trend that is opposed by a good deal of our scientists here, particularly the older group again.
They kind of like to see their grant come from NSF, and they do their thing and continue doing what they want to do.
I don't think this is going to be possible.
The world is changing, and people have to change with it.
And that's the way it's changing.
toward the more applied.
I think if we're to survive as a first-rate institution, we're going to have to change with the world.
Follow this.
And do more applied research.
Do more applied.
Do you think Sea Grant will play a larger and larger role in funding applying?
Not necessarily.
I think things like Sea Grant, unless Sea Grant changes, I don't think that's going to be necessarily the key thing.
But I think research of that general nature will become more and more important.
Now, it may grow through Sea Grant.
I don't know.
With Ned Estenso running Sea Grant, he's a very capable guy, and
You might be able to generate the funding and the change of emphasis of Sea Grant so that that will play a major role.
Certainly those kinds of research.
I think that's a little shorter term than I'm thinking about.
I look at us getting in the applied research, but the longer term applied research than looking right at today's problems, sort of anticipating tomorrow's problems.
not the far-out research that's just looking at the understanding of what's going on, but the longer-term problems.
And I don't think Sea Grant is putting an awful lot of its effort on that.
I think the IDOE is more closely related to those kinds of things.
It's somewhere in between those two that I suspect will have a major impact in the future.
I'm going to turn the tape over here.
